Deep-Learning-Animal-ReID-Survey

      From Closed-Set Biometrics to Open-World Animal ReID: A Survey of Deep Learning for Animal Re-Identification

      A Survey of Deep Learning for Animal Re-Identification

      A living repository accompanying our survey.

      Deep Learning for Animal Re-Identification

      The official living repository for the survey:
      From Closed-Set Biometrics to Open-World Animal ReID: A Survey of Deep Learning for Animal Re-Identification

      Figure 1: Publication trend and keyword evolution in Animal ReID.

      ğŸ“– Abstract

      Animal ReID enables individual-level monitoring for wildlife conservation and precision agriculture, yet reliable real-world deployment remains challenging. Recent advances in foundation models have substantially improved generalization, extending Animal ReID beyond species-specific, closed-set recognition to settings involving unseen individuals and even unseen species. However, practical deployments operate in open-world environments that impose multiple requirements, including robustness to non-stationary appearance distributions, accommodation of evolving populations, and recognition of observations outside known identity and species spaces.

      This survey provides a systematic review of appearance-based Animal ReID from a generalization perspective, clarifying how modern deep learning paradigms have reshaped the problem landscape. Based on an analysis of 204 representative studies, we propose a method-centric taxonomy that organizes prior work according to how performance gains are achieved in practice. We also examine existing evaluation protocols through a principled zero-shot benchmark analysis. Beyond algorithmic advances, we adopt an ecosystem-level perspective that spans data acquisition, model training, decision-making, and deployment feedback, discussing ethical risks, and releasing open resources, including a standardized toolkit and a living repository, to support reproducible research and long-term community use.

      ğŸš€ Released Resources

      To support reproducibility and long-term community use, this repository serves as a living companion to the survey and provides:

      • ğŸ“š Paper List: A continuously updated paper list covering representative Animal ReID research;
      • ğŸ› ï¸ VIGIL-ReID Toolkit: A standardized evaluation library designed for open-world settings.
        ğŸ‘‰ Get Started with Toolkit
      • ğŸ† Benchmark Results: Detailed performance analysis and zero-shot baselines extracted from the survey.
        ğŸ‘‰ View Leaderboard & Analysis

      Scope and Coverage

      The paper list below covers representative research on appearance-based Animal Re-Identification, spanning closed-set, open-set, and open-world settings. It includes works on data-centric methods, representation learning, multimodal and foundation-model-based approaches, as well as evaluation protocols and deployment considerations. This list is curated to accompany the survey and will be continuously updated as the field evolves.

      Quick Links

      Papers sorted by year: | 2025 | 2024 | 2023 | 2022 | 2021 | 2020 | 2019 | 2018 | 2017 | 2016 | 2015 | 2014 | 2013 | 2012 | 2011 | 2010 | 2009 | 2008 | 2007 | 2006 | 2005 | 2004 | 2003 | 2002 | 2001 | 2000 | 1999 | 1998 | 1990

      Paper List

      Notes on Columns:

      • Unseen: Indicates whether the method explicitly addresses settings with unseen identities or species (e.g., Open-Set, Zero-Shot, or Any-Animal scenarios).
      • Venue: We prioritize listing top-tier Computer Science / Computer Vision conferences (e.g., CVPR, ICCV, ECCV, NeurIPS). For brevity, venues for some interdisciplinary or biological journals may be leave blank.
